conclusion: This problem involves electromagnetic induction in a rotating system.
Analyze the problem step by step.
Metal shaft OO' can rotate with angular velocity ω.
Metal rod M is fixed perpendicular to OO' and rotates with it.
The other end of M slides along a fixed metal ring N.
There is a uniform magnetic field parallel to OO' with magnitude B₀.
A voltmeter V measures the potential difference between OO' and ring N.
When angular velocity is ω = ω₀, the voltmeter reading is U₀.
If magnetic field changes to nB₀, determine angular velocity for voltmeter to read mU₀.
Involves Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction; EMF depends on rate of change of magnetic flux.
Rod M generates an EMF due to motion through the magnetic field.
EMF magnitude follows the formula: ε ∝ B · ω · L².
Under initial conditions: U₀ ∝ B₀ · ω₀.
Under new conditions: mU₀ ∝ nB₀ · ω.
Set up equation: mU₀/U₀ = nB₀ · ω / B₀ · ω₀.
Simplify to: m = n · ω / ω₀.
Solve for ω: ω = (m · ω₀) / n.
Increasing magnetic field (n > 1) requires less angular velocity for same EMF; more voltage (m > 1) requires higher angular velocity or stronger magnetic field.
